title: The SPAR Ontologies

author: Silvio Peroni, Department of Computer Science and Engineering (DISI), University of Bologna

segmentation: OK, I'm sorry, but only from the University of Bologna and I'm one of the two main developers of this suite of ontologies called Semantic Publishing and referencing Ontology's parent Ologist for friends basically, and that I've started to implement basically since 2010 when I was a shy PhD student.
Anne was an intern at the Oxford University in Zoology Department, the laboratory in Zoology Department was run by.
David shut down.
There was professor of molecular biology there, but had an entire group of computer scientists working on semantic publishing things that is different from what you used to teach.
Basically at that time in the class.

So the setting of this work is semantic publishing that has been defined by the witch shattering wonderful article in 2009, which is basically the use of web and semantic web technologies for announcing scholarly work that could be a scholarly paper or Journal article.
For instance, mandatory debt or even datasets, and so on, in a semantic way.
By using, for instance, RDF triples, nano publication and this kind of stuff attached to the articles come out.

We have the academic community as well.

To provide a set of complementary antag orthogonal ontology model for describing the different aspects of the publishing domain at that time, there weren't a lot of ontology available for describing these data.

There were some exceptions, like Bebo for instance, or very general models like this in terms or Ferber, but there weren't at that time full set of complete ontological modules for describing all the aspect concerning this color domain and the publishing domain in general.

And of course, for each ontology we have available in HTML documentation.
A lot of these ontologies are also included in the linked open vocabulary data set an we are in the process of adding even the new one.
There an I hope to we will finish it in a few in a few months.

The 1st of this principle is we wanted to enable enable the adoption of these ontologies and from doing that.

Terms for describing these word, but usually the terms that we that they were available were quite generic, like for example Ferber.

Say theories that are not understandable at all for the user that are working in the publishing domain, such as the publisher that knows about Journal articles, conference papers, this kind of stuff, but not about this kind of very generic concept.
So we started to basically interview alot the people involved in the scholarly community and the publishing domain in order to retrieve appropriate vocabulary to use in the ontologies and self.
Another important thing is that we wanted to avoid to create just one monolithic ontology, a big moderating ontology.
Because we are for the experience that we had even even in past.

It is easier basically to have one module that describe exactly address exactly 1 specific aspect of the domain and then to make this model interoperable, easy in and easy way somehow with the other models that are within the spa ecosystem but also with other external ontologies.

That aspect of the publishing domain, for instance, meta data over paper instead of agents.
Role of the people involved in the publishing domain.
Third requirement principle.
The idea is that we have noticed and I think I don't have to explain this to this community.
Honestly that adding a lot of constraint in the ontology in terms of restriction is of course a very good ontological engineering thing.
But usually having a quite complex ontology from that perspective is not so good for enabling the reuse of these ontology in different contexts.

There are a lot of ontologies that are very well known very well used in this community like 4th, and they have a very limited amount of constraint there, and this is one of the key success of their broad adoption.
Another point is the reuse of existing vocabulary.
We are quite extensively reusing.
Ontologies that have been already accepted and used by the community for addressing specific aspects.
4th is an example, but also DC terms scores for defining exactly those concepts.
So we are directly reusing them.
And also we are using a lot of ontology design pattern for creating the new part of the ontology so as to follow quite good guidelines for their constructions.
But in my opinion the most important development principle that we had to deal with.
